questions.text:
A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department seeking evaluation for back pain. The pain began three hours ago when he fell while climbing a flight of stairs. He reports that the pain is worse with movement and improves when he lies down in bed. The patient has not had recent night sweats or unintentional weight loss. Past medical history is notable for osteoporosis and benign prostatic hyperplasia managed with prazosin. Vitals are within normal limits. Cardiac and pulmonary examination are noncontributory. Musculoskeletal exam is notable for tenderness over the thoracic spine. Neurological exam is notable for 3+ reflexes in the lower extremities and 2+ reflexes in the upper extremities. In addition, the patient has reduced sensation to soft touch and pinprick in the lower extremities. Imaging is ordered, and the results are as follows:



Reproduced from: Radiopedia  

Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a spinal compression fracture secondary to osteoporosis. Most patients with osteoporosis are generally asymptomatic until a fracture occurs. Symptoms of a spinal compression fracture include height loss, back pain, and kyphosis (excess outward curvature of the spine).  Neurological symptoms such as reduced sensation, reduced strength, and hyperreflexia in the lower extremities may be seen if the fracture causes spinal cord compression.

Radiographic imaging will often show vertebral height loss, retropulsed fragment (fracture fragment displaced into the spinal canal), or sharp fracture lines. Of note, there is prominent vertebral height loss in the image presented in this vignette (see Figure 1).  

Figure 1: Spinal Compression Fracture with Annotation  


The majority of patients with a spinal compression fracture without neurological symptoms are treated with conservative pain management. Medications used include acetaminophen, NSIADs, and opioid analgesics. Bisphosphonates can be used for the long-term management of osteoporosis. For patients with neurological deficits, surgical intervention should be performed to decompress the spinal cord.  

Option Analysis

❌ Order a PET-CT scan  :
Incorrect: A PET-CT scan can be used to detect occult malignancies. Metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine can result in compression fractures. However, this patient has no constitutional symptoms of cancer, such as night sweats or cachexia. Moreover, the patient’s recent fall provides a more likely explanation for the spinal fracture.
❌ Initiate ibuprofen treatment:
Incorrect: Analgesics such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can be used for pain management after a spinal fracture. However this patient also has neurological deficits, which are concerning for spinal cord compression, and surgical intervention is warranted.  
❌ Initiate bisphosphonate treatment:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates can be used for long-term osteoporosis management. However, they are not used in the management of acute spinal fractures secondary to osteoporosis.
✅ Surgical decompression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Provide back brace:
Incorrect: A back brace can give support and reduce spinal range of movement. It can be used to manage spinal fractures that do not have neurological symptoms. However, this patient has increased reflexes and decreased sensation in the lower extremities. These findings raise concerns for spinal cord compression, and surgical management is necessary.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents due to left leg pain. During the past four months, she has been experiencing left thigh pain that is worse at night and aggravated by movement. She did not have an associated injury or trauma to the area prior to symptom onset. She has also had intermittent night sweats and an unintentional weight loss of 8 lbs. (3.6 kg). Temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), heart rate is 96/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and blood pressure is 103/61 mmHg. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness to palpation of the left proximal thigh with overlying erythema and a palpable tender mass. Plain radiographs of the left femur show a large lytic lesion with a poorly defined border and a periosteal reaction with an “onion peel” appearance. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 12-year-old girl presents with a four-month history of atraumatic left thigh pain that is worse at night and associated with night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Physical examination reveals a palpable, tender mass with overlying erythema, and plain radiographs showed a lytic lesion with poorly defined borders and periosteal reaction. These findings strongly suggest an aggressive or malignant bone tumor, such as Ewing sarcoma. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) should be performed next to help make the diagnosis, followed by bone biopsy for confirmation and staging and likely additional imaging to evaluate for metastases.

Plain radiographs can be initially used when bone lesions are suspected to assess for high-risk features (e.g., poorly defined borders, lytic or sclerotic lesion, periosteal reaction) that suggest malignant or aggressive/ destructive lesions (i.e., aneurysmal bone cyst). If any high-risk findings are detected on radiography as in this case, then MRI should be performed next to help make the diagnosis. Bone biopsy should be performed for histologic confirmation and staging. Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcomas and Ewing sarcomas. Aneurysmal bone cysts are aggressive non-malignant bone tumors that can have high-risk findings on radiographs.

Benign bone tumors often have characteristic radiograph features and can be diagnosed by radiograph alone. Further evaluation may include MRI and computed tomography (CT) if the lesions are not benign based on radiography or are in areas that are hard to see with a radiograph such as the spine, scapula, ribs, or pelvis.
   

Image courtesy of STATdx 
Figure 1. Classic case of Ewing sarcoma (ES) of the long bone in a 12-year-old boy is shown. There is a permeative lesion in the distal fibular diaphysis (white solid arrow) associated with lamellar periosteal reaction also known as onion skinning (white open arrow) and cortex disruption (white curved arrow).  

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT)  :
Incorrect: While CT can be useful to localize a bone lesion and assess its characteristics, it does not provide the accuracy and resolution that an MRI provides for visualizing bone tumors. This patient likely has an aggressive or malignant bone tumor based on the presence of high-risk findings on radiograph and further imaging via MRI is warranted.  
❌ Radionuclide bone scan :
Incorrect: A radionuclide bone scan is used to evaluate the entire skeleton for metastases. It is not useful for diagnosing a primary bone tumor. This patient likely has an aggressive or malignant bone tumor based on the presence of high-risk findings on radiograph and the best next step is further imaging via MRI to better evaluate the primary lesion. 
❌ Positron emission tomography (PET)  :
Incorrect: PET imaging is used to assess distant metastases and for staging. This patient likely has an aggressive or malignant bone tumor based on the presence of high-risk findings on radiograph and the best next step is further imaging via MRI to better evaluate the primary lesion. 
❌ Ultrasonography :
Incorrect: Ultrasound is helpful for diagnosing disorders of soft tissue structures, but it is not used to diagnose bone lesions. This patient likely has an aggressive or malignant bone tumor based on the presence of high-risk findings on radiograph and the best next step is further imaging via MRI to better evaluate the primary lesion.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to right leg pain. Several weeks ago, he developed pain in the right leg that is worse at night and has been increasing in intensity. There was no preceding injury or trauma. The pain resolves quickly with naproxen. He has had no associated fever, chills, weight loss, or rash. Vital signs are within normal limits.  The patient is well-appearing and is not in acute distress. Physical examination reveals localized tenderness to palpation and swelling at the right proximal thigh with limited range of motion of the right hip. Plain radiographs of the right hip and femur are ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 12-year-old boy presents with several weeks of right leg pain without a preceding injury. The pain is worse at night. Physical examination shows localized tenderness and swelling of the right proximal thigh and limited range of motion of the hip. The pain adequately responds to the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as naproxen. Based on this constellation of findings, the most likely diagnosis is an osteoid osteoma.

Pediatric patients with bone tumors typically present between the ages of 10-20. They may have localized bone pain and, in some cases, localized swelling or a palpable mass. Occasionally, there is limited range of motion of the adjacent joint. The findings may be associated with a pathologic fracture. Malignant bone tumors may be associated with a dull pain that awakens the child from sleep at night and associated systemic findings, such as fatigue, malaise, fever, and weight loss.

Patients with benign bone lesions may present with pain, but often patients are asymptomatic, and the bone lesions are found incidentally when radiographs are obtained for other reasons, such as trauma. Osteochondromas and non-ossifying fibromas are typically asymptomatic and found incidentally. Patients with Langerhans cell histiocytosis may present with localized pain and multisystem involvement.

Osteoid osteomas are benign bone tumors that have a nidus of prostaglandin-producing cells. Patients with osteoid osteomas typically present with pain that is worse at night and resolves quickly (within 20 to 25 minutes) with the use of NSAIDS (i.e., prostaglandin inhibitors). If a patient with a bone lesion has bone pain that does not resolve quickly with NSAIDs, other diagnoses should be considered.
       

Option Analysis

✅ Osteoid osteoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteochondroma:
Incorrect: Osteochondroma is a benign bone lesion that is often asymptomatic and detected incidentally when radiographs are done for a different reason (e.g. trauma). The most common location of an osteochondroma is the distal femur, whereas the most common location of an osteoid osteoma is the proximal femur. The location of this patient’s pain, in addition to the degree of pain and the fact that it is worse at night and relieved with naproxen, makes osteoid osteoma the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Non-ossifying fibroma  :
Incorrect: Non-ossifying fibroma is an asymptomatic benign bone lesion that is typically seen as an incidental finding when radiographs are done for a different reason (e.g. trauma). The most common location of a non-ossifying fibroma is the distal femur, whereas the most common location of an osteoid osteoma is the proximal femur. The patient’s pain, in addition to its location at the proximal femur and relief with naproxen, makes osteoid osteoma the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Simple bone cyst:
Incorrect: Simple bone cysts typically present in the setting of pathologic fractures, otherwise they are usually asymptomatic. This patient has significant pain that is worse at night and responds to naproxen, which is consistent with an osteoid osteoma.  
❌ Langerhans cell histiocytosis:
Incorrect: Langerhans cell histiocytosis can present with localized bone pain but typically causes systemic symptoms, such as rash. In addition, this patient’s pain is worse at night and relieved with naproxen, making osteoid osteoma the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the pediatric clinic because of several weeks of dull localized left upper arm pain that is worse at night. He has not had recent trauma and has not done any strenuous physical activity recently. He has no fever or weight loss. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg. He is well-appearing, comfortable, and not in acute pain. Physical examination reveals a large, tender, palpable soft tissue mass in the left proximal upper arm. Plain radiographs of the left arm are ordered. Which of the following imaging findings would be the most concerning for malignancy?

choices.text: Sclerotic borders around a well-defined lesion

questions.solution:
This 16-year-old boy presents with several weeks of localized bone pain that is worse at night and not associated with trauma or systemic symptoms. Physical examination reveals a large tender soft tissue mass increasing the index of suspicion for a bone tumor, most likely an osteosarcoma. Radiography is used to help diagnose bone tumors in children, and findings can indicate if the lesion has high-risk features consistent with malignant or destructive lesions or minimal risk features consistent with benign lesions. The finding of a lesion with poorly defined borders is a high-risk feature that is associated with malignant tumors.

Pediatric bone tumors may be benign or malignant and must be diagnosed and treated promptly since malignant tumors can be limb- or life-threatening. A plain radiograph is used to assess for high-risk features which include poorly defined borders, sclerotic lesions, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. High-risk features are associated with malignant bone tumors including osteosarcomas and Ewing sarcomas, as well as benign, yet destructive, aneurysmal bone cysts.

Benign bone tumors/lesions are not associated with high-risk findings on radiography. Benign bone tumors include osteoid osteomas, osteochondromas, non-ossifying fibromas, simple bone cysts, and Langerhans cell histiocytosis. If any high-risk findings are detected on radiography, then magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) should be performed. Bone biopsy should be done for histologic confirmation and staging.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Lesion with poorly defined borders:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lesion without periosteal reaction:
Incorrect: The presence of an aggressive periosteal reaction, (i.e., new bone production in the periosteum caused by irritation), is alarming and considered a high-risk finding associated with malignancy. Alternatively, lack of periosteal reaction is more suggestive of a non-malignant, less-aggressive lesion, though lack of periosteal reaction does not exclude a malignant lesion. In addition to an aggressive periosteal reaction, lesions with poorly defined borders, and sclerotic lesions on x-ray are concerning for malignancy. 
❌ Sclerotic borders around a well-defined lesion:
Incorrect: While a sclerotic lesion is a high-risk finding associated with malignancy, the finding of sclerotic borders around a well-defined lesion is indicative of a benign bone lesion. In addition to sclerotic lesions, lesions with poorly defined borders and an aggressive periosteal reaction on x-ray are concerning for malignancy.  
❌ Well-defined lytic lesion:
Incorrect: Non-ossifying fibromas and Langerhans cell histiocytosis can be seen on radiographs as well-defined lytic lesions. These are both benign bone lesions. X-ray findings of sclerotic lesions, and lesions with poorly defined borders, or an aggressive periosteal reaction are concerning for malignancy. 
❌ Cartilage-capped bony spur :
Incorrect: Osteochondromas are benign lesions that appear as cartilage-capped bony spurs on radiography. X-ray findings of sclerotic lesions and lesions with poorly defined borders or an aggressive periosteal reaction are concerning for malignancy.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate a nodule on the wrist. The nodule appeared on the right wrist one month ago and has slightly increased in size since then. She has not experienced any pain or limitations in her daily activities but is worried it “might be cancerous.” Past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. She does not smoke, consume alcohol, or use illicit substances. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for the findings demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s clinical condition?  


 Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an asymptomatic nodule on the volar aspect of the wrist. This presentation is most consistent with a ganglion cyst based on the above image. In the absence of significant pain or limitations in functional mobility, she should be treated with close observation and surveillance.

Ganglion cysts are the most common soft tissue tumor of the hand. They arise from mucoid degeneration of periarticular structures and outpouching of synovial membranes lining the tendinous sheaths. Clinically, they present most commonly on the dorsal surface of the wrist as a firm, rubbery, smooth nodule (though they can also present on the volar aspect of the wrist, as with this patient). Ganglion cysts are most commonly painless. However, some may become inflamed and cause pain with repetitive wrist activity.

In most cases, ganglion cysts should be treated conservatively with reassurance and close observation as approximately 50% will self-resolve without treatment. If the cyst causes pain or limitations in daily activities, needle aspiration can be attempted. However, many ganglion cysts will recur despite treatment. Finally, surgical excision can be considered if the ganglion cyst is refractory to needle aspiration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reassurance and observation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Needle aspiration  :
Incorrect: Needle aspiration is recommended for ganglion cysts that are bothersome or inflamed. However, more than half of ganglion cysts that are aspirated will recur. This patient does not have symptoms associated with the ganglion cyst. As a result, reassurance and observation would be a better approach.  
❌ Surgical excision  :
Incorrect: Surgical excision is not recommended for the treatment of ganglion cysts. For bothersome or inflamed cysts, needle aspiration is generally preferred over surgical excision.  
❌ Topical nifedipine:
Incorrect: Topical nifedipine is used to treat external hemorrhoids, not ganglion cysts.  
❌ Screw and plate fixation  :
Incorrect: Fractures of wrist and hand bones can be repaired via screw and plate fixation. Fractures can present with pain, reduced range of motion, and overlying soft tissue swelling. In contrast, this patient has an asymptomatic nodule over the volar aspect of the wrist, which is more suggestive of a ganglion cyst.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of an abdominal mass.  The patient reports that the mass has been present for several months, and he has had no associated pain. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which the patient takes hydrochlorothiazide and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 125/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 80/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.  Physical examination reveals a non-tender, round, rubbery, mobile mass as shown in the image below. The mass is not reducible on palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

 Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a non-tender, round, rubbery, mobile abdominal wall mass that is consistent with a lipoma. Management of lipomas typically involves monitoring if they are asymptomatic and small, or excision if they are symptomatic or large.

Physical examination can often help determine the type lesion present in patients who present with abdominal wall masses. If the mass is reducible with direct palpation, it is likely a hernia.  Additional findings that suggest this diagnosis include enlargement of the mass with coughing or Valsalva maneuvers. If the mass appears fluctuant, or there are associated infectious symptoms such as fever or chills, the mass may represent an abscess. If the mass is irreducible; firm and fixed; and associated with weight loss, or constitutional symptoms it may be a malignant mass. A nontender, rubbery and non-reducible mass is consistent with a lipoma if it is mobile, as seen in this patient, or a desmoid tumor if it is fixed. Biopsy or advanced imaging may be needed to make the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lipoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Desmoid tumor:
Incorrect: In contrast to a lipoma, a desmoid tumor is a fixed, firm mass. This patient’s mass is mobile and rubbery consistent with a lipoma.  
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: A rectus sheath hematoma is unlikely to occur inpatients who are not taking anticoagulants or have not experienced trauma. Rectal sheath hematomas typically present as tender, nonpulsatile abdominal wall masses that may have overlying ecchymoses. This patient’s mass is non-tender, mobile, and rubbery which is consistent with a lipoma.  
❌ Seroma:
Incorrect: A seroma presents as a fluctuant mass. This patient’s mass is non-tender, mobile, and rubbery consistent with a lipoma.  
❌ Ventral hernia:
Incorrect: A ventral wall hernia will typically present as a reducible mass over the anterior abdomen. This patient’s mass is non-tender, non-reducible, mobile, and rubbery consistent with a lipoma.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of an enlarging abdominal wall mass present that has been present for the past six months. The patient has no abdominal pain, weight loss, fever or anorexia. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, pulse is 90/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows an irreducible, non-tender, firm and fixed mass over the lower mid abdomen. There is no erythema, warmth, or fluctuance. There is no regional lymphadenopathy. An MRI of the abdomen shows a homogeneous well-circumscribed mass in the abdominal wall. Biopsy is performed. Which of the following histopathologic findings is consistent with the most likely type of mass?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a slowly enlarging abdominal wall mass that is non-tender, firm and fixed. MRI shows a homogeneous well-circumscribed mass which would be most consistent with a desmoid tumor. On pathologic analysis, fibroblastic proliferation, spindle cells, and abundant fibrous stroma would be seen with a desmoid tumor.

The diagnostic workup for patients with an abdominal wall mass is guided by history and physical examination. If an underlying mass is reducible with direct palpation, then it is likely a hernia and would not require further imaging, unless there is concern for incarceration or strangulation. For solid masses, further diagnostic testing may need to be performed. A nontender, small, round, rubbery, mobile mass is consistent with a lipoma that would not require further imaging. However a mass that is slow growing, large, and solid requires imaging with MRI or CT and biopsy to rule out potential malignancy. Masses that are fluctuant may be either seromas or abscesses and ultrasonography followed by aspiration should be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fibroblastic proliferation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Malignant cells:
Incorrect: Malignant cells would be seen on biopsy of a malignant abdominal wall mass. This patient does not have regional lymphadenopathy or constitutional symptoms consistent with malignancy and MRI shows a homogenous well circumcised mass that is more consistent with a desmoid tumor.  
❌ Lipoid cells:
Incorrect:  On physical exam, a lipoma is typically a nontender, round, rubbery, mobile mass. Biopsy would show lipoid cells. This patient’s mass is irreducible and firm which is more consistent with a desmoid tumor which would show fibroblastic proliferation on pathology.  
❌ Gram-positive cocci in clusters:
Incorrect: Gram-positive cocci in clusters (i.e. Staphylococcus) may be found in an abdominal wall abscess; which would present as an erythematous, warm, fluctuant mass. This patient’s mass is a non-tender, firm and fixed mass without erythema, warmth, or fluctuance which is more consistent with a desmoid tumor.  
❌ Hypocellular fluid:
Incorrect: Hypocellular fluid would be consistent with biopsy findings from a seroma. This patient's non-tender, firm and fixed mass is more consistent with a desmoid tumor which would show fibroblastic proliferation on pathology.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician due to persistent right wrist pain. The patient has been experiencing pain on the thumb-side of the wrist every time she holds or grips an object. She recently delivered a healthy, full-term baby four weeks ago. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, swelling and tenderness to palpation are noted at the radial aspect of the right wrist. Repetitive tapping over the volar part of the wrist does not reproduce the pain. While the patient is grasping the right thumb with the right four digits, the physician places the wrist in ulnar deviation. This maneuver reproduces the pain. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis
Entrapment and compression of the median nerve
Outpouching of the synovial membranes lining tendinous sheaths
Occult fracture of the distal radius

questions.solution:
This patient presents in the postpartum period with pain over the radial aspect of the wrist and a positive Finklestein test. These findings are consistent with De Quervain tenosynovitis, characterized by myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

De Quervain tenosynovitis reflects a non-inflammatory thickening of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis as they cross the radial styloid process and through the first extensor compartment. Clinically, patients will experience pain at the radial aspect of the wrist. The pain is exacerbated when gripping objects or performing repetitive movements involving the thumb. Risk factors include female sex, being in the postpartum period, and prolonged abduction and extension of the thumb.

The most useful diagnostic aid in evaluating DeQuervain tenosynovitis is the Finklestein test. The thumb is flexed and held inside a fist to perform this test. Afterward, the wrist is moved in the ulnar direction. A positive test is characterized by pain at the radial styloid process or along the length of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis with ulnar deviation of the wrist.

Treatment is primarily conservative and involves rest, analgesia, and wrist splinting. Advanced or refractory cases are typically treated with glucocorticoids or surgery.  

Option Analysis

✅ Myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Entrapment and compression of the median nerve  :
Incorrect: Carpal tunnel syndrome typically presents with a positive Tinel test, which involves tapping over the median nerve and evaluating reproducible pain or paresthesia. This patient’s negative Tinel test and positive Finklestein test are more indicative of De Quervain tenosynovitis.  
❌ Outpouching of the synovial membranes lining tendinous sheaths  :
Incorrect: Ganglion cysts are clinically characterized by their round appearance and rubbery texture. No such structures are present on this patient’s physical examination.  
❌ Occult fracture of the distal radius:
Incorrect: A fracture of the distal radius is unlikely without associated trauma.  
❌ Calcium hydroxyapatite arthropathy  :
Incorrect: As the name implies, hydroxyapatite crystal deposition disease (HADD) is characterized by periarticular and intraarticular deposition of hydroxyapatite cysts. While HADD is on the differential for atraumatic swelling and pain of the wrist, this patient has a positive Finklestein test, making DeQuervain tenosynovitis a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with right ring finger pain. The patient recalls that the right ring finger has been “catching and locking” for weeks. The symptoms seem to improve throughout the day, with gradual “unlocking” as the day progresses. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which he takes metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates the fourth digit of the right hand to be in a flexed position, as shown below. Passive extension of the digit is met with some resistance. There are no palpable nodules or tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath. Nonetheless, he can fully extend the digit with minimal pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient has intermittent locking and catching of the fourth digit and difficulty extending the finger from a flexed position. This clinical presentation is most consistent with trigger finger, also termed stenosing tenosynovitis.

Trigger finger is a flexor tendon that catches when it attempts to glide through a stenotic sheath, resulting in an inability to flex or extend the finger smoothly. The underlying pathology of this disease remains unclear but is thought to be due to fibrocartilaginous metaplasia of the ligamentous layer of the tendon sheath. The majority of cases are idiopathic, although some are associated with repetitive hand motions, often from occupational activities.

Clinically, patients experience a catching and locking sensation of the finger that progressively worsens over time. Patients may also experience pain localized over the volar aspect of the metacarpophalangeal joint.  

Treatment is primarily conservative and involves splinting, analgesia, and rest. Local glucocorticoid injection can also be administered. Patients who are refractory to conservative management or glucocorticoid injections may warrant the surgical release of the flexor tendon.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stenosing tenosynovitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dupuytren contracture  :
Incorrect: A Dupuytren contracture is characterized by slow, progressive fibroproliferation of the palmar fascia. Patients typically have a palpable cord or nodules along the flexor tendon sheath.  
❌ Flexor tenosynovitis  :
Incorrect: Flexor tenosynovitis is a surgical emergency and refers to a deep space infection of the flexor tendon sheath. Patients can present with pain with passive extension, tenderness over the entire length of the flexor tendon sheath, symmetric finger swelling along the length of the tendon sheath, and flexed posture of the affected finger.
❌ Mallet finger  :
Incorrect: Mallet finger refers to an injury to the extensor digitorum as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. This injury results in an inability to extend the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.  
❌ Jersey finger  :
Incorrect: Jersey finger refers to an injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. This injury results in an inability to flex the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate bilateral wrist pain. The patient has worse pain at night and is associated with paresthesias of the first, second, third, and half of the fourth finger. She states, “I need to figure out what is going on. I can barely sleep at night.” Past medical history includes hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, rheumatoid arthritis, and obesity. She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks two to three beers nightly. She currently works as an office secretary. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination does not reveal any deformity or swelling of the wrist. Which of the following will best assist in diagnosing this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve, and she has multiple risk factors for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome. Of the tests listed, the Phalen maneuver is most likely to reveal the underlying diagnosis.

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a multifactorial disease that primarily results from increased pressure in the intercarpal canal and associated compression of the median nerve. Median nerve compression manifests clinically with pain and paresthesias in the first three digits of the hand and half of the fourth digit. Pain and paresthesias are then often reproduced with movements that flex or extend the wrist.

Special maneuvers that aid in diagnosis include the Phalen test and Tinel test. In the Phalen test, the patient fully flexes the palms at the wrist with the elbow in full extension to provide extra pressure on the median nerve. The Phalen test is positive if these maneuvers elicit pain or paresthesia. The Tinel test involves repetitive tapping over the carpal tunnel and evaluating for reproducible pain or paresthesia. Further diagnostic tests include nerve conduction studies and electromyography to rule out other polyneuropathies, plexopathies, and radiculopathies.

Treatment is primarily conservative, with physical therapy and wrist splinting as mainstays for mild or moderate disease. Additional therapies include oral or injection corticosteroids. Surgical release of the median nerve is reserved for cases that are refractory to conservative measures or those with advanced disease, characterized by evidence of axonal loss on nerve conduction studies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Phalen maneuver  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Finkelstein test:
Incorrect: The Finkelstein test is a physical examination maneuver used to determine if there is tenosynovitis in the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons of the wrist. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the median nerve distribution, more consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hook test:
Incorrect: Distal biceps tendon rupture can be diagnosed using the hook test. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the median nerve distribution, more consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ CT of the wrist  :
Incorrect: CT of the wrist is generally non-contributory in evaluating carpal tunnel syndrome unless there is a concern for a compressive mass lesion.  
❌ MRI of the wrist  :
Incorrect: Like CT, MRI of the wrist is generally non-contributory in evaluating carpal tunnel syndrome unless there is a concern for a compressive mass lesion.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening stiffness in the right hand. Over the past several months, the patient has had difficulty extending the right ring finger. He states, “I feel like my finger is under constant tension. I think my father had a similar condition.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right hand is notable for the findings demonstrated below. Further evaluation of the patient’s medical history will likely reveal which of the following?  


 Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of a Dupuytren contracture on physical examination. The condition is associated with a history of diabetes mellitus.

A Dupuytren contracture is characterized by slow, progressive fibroproliferation of the palmar fascia. The underlying etiology of this condition is unclear. However, this disease has several risk factors, including diabetes mellitus, chronic alcohol use, repetitive hand use, vibratory trauma, and smoking. In addition, there is a component of genetic predisposition, with a majority of patients being men of northern European ancestry.  

Clinically, Dupuytren contractures manifest with nodules on the palmar fascia and fingers. The nodules gradually lose flexibility and contract, resulting in the affected fingers being drawn into flexion. This condition is usually painless. However, Dupuytren contractures can become painful if the underlying tendon sheaths become inflamed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diabetes mellitus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension has not been independently associated with the development of Dupuytren contractures.  
❌ Hyperlipidemia  :
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia has not been independently associated with the development of Dupuytren contractures.  
❌ Previous hand surgery  :
Incorrect: There is currently debate as to whether prior hand trauma or surgery lends towards the development of Dupuytren contracture. In contrast, diabetes mellitus is a well-documented risk factor for the development of this condition.  
❌ Epilepsy  :
Incorrect: Epilepsy is not a known risk factor for the development of Dupuytren contractures.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate bilateral wrist discomfort. The patient has had worsening pain and numbness over the first, second, and third digits and half of the fourth digit. She recently started working as a secretary and spends most of the day typing on a keyboard. She is currently undergoing treatment for breast cancer with anastrozole. The patient’s other medical problems include obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperthyroidism. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for reproducible pain and paresthesias with a tapping of the volar aspect of the wrist. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve and a positive Tinel test. These findings are consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome. Aromatase inhibitors have been shown to increase tendon thickness, which is thought to contribute to the development of median nerve entrapment.

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a multifactorial disease that primarily results from increased pressure in the intercarpal canal and associated compression of the median nerve. Median nerve compression manifests clinically with pain and paresthesias in the first three digits of the hand and half of the fourth digit. Pain and paresthesias are then often reproduced with movements that flex or extend the wrist.

Additional risk factors include obesity, female sex, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, and hypothyroidism. Workplace factors are also thought to contribute, with duties requiring repetitive hand and wrist use contributing to disease development.

Treatment is primarily conservative, with physical therapy and wrist splinting as mainstays of treatment, while surgery is reserved for advanced disease or cases refractory to conservative measures.

Option Analysis

✅ Aromatase-inhibitor use  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not a known risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Smoking  :
Incorrect: Smoking is not a known risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia may contribute to obesity, a known risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome. However, the patient’s use of aromatase-inhibitors is a more significant and direct risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism, is a risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the clinic with worsening knee pain for the past 5 months. He is currently training for a marathon, and the pain is brought on by running. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medications. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation over the lateral knee superior to the joint line at the lateral femoral epicondyle. There is no joint swelling of the knee and no gapping at the knee with valgus or varus testing. In addition, a test is performed that results in failure of the hip to adduct and lateral knee pain when the patient is lying with the affected side up and the distal leg is held with the hip abducted and extended and then dropped until motion is restricted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening lateral knee pain while engaged in running. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation at the lateral femoral epicondyle and a positive Ober test. These findings are consistent with iliotibial band syndrome.

Iliotibial band syndrome is an overuse pain syndrome wherein pain occurs at the lateral knee as the iliotibial band crosses over the lateral femoral epicondyle. It is described as a sharp or burning pain that occurs only during activity. It is a common overuse syndrome often seen in runners and cyclists. Risk factors include weak hip adductors that place increased rotational strain on the iliotibial band, as well as an inherited leg-length discrepancy.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, and advanced imaging is not needed. Key clinical findings include pain at the lateral femoral epicondyle and a positive Ober test or Noble test. For the Ober test, the knee is flexed to 90 °, the hip is abducted and extended, and the leg is released. Failure of the knee to adduct is a positive test and pain may be noted at the lateral knee. For the Noble test, the patient is supine, and the knee is bent back and forth several times from 0° to 90° while applying firm pressure on the lateral femoral epicondyle while the patient actively extends the hip and knee. The presence of palpable snapping, crepitus, or localized pain signifies a positive test.

Treatment of iliotibial band syndrome involves providing symptomatic relief and prescribing activity restriction, and physical therapy to correct mobility deficits.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliotibial band syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral meniscus tear:
Incorrect: Pain from lateral meniscal tears occurs at the joint line which is inferior to the location of the pain associated with iliotibial band syndrome. Lateral meniscus tears are typically associated with joint pain and swelling after an injury which this patient has not had..  
❌ Lateral collateral ligament tear:
Incorrect: While iliotibial band syndrome and lateral collateral ligament tears can occur concomitantly, it is unlikely given this patient has no knee gapping with stress testing on physical examination. Lateral collateral ligament tears typically occur after a high-energy blow to the knee or with extreme varus bending, neither of which have occurred in this patient.  
❌ Biceps femoris tendinopathy:
Incorrect: In this condition, tenderness is present at the tendon insertion at the lateral aspect of the fibular head rather than at the lateral femoral epicondyle. Pain is typically at the posterior aspect of the knee and outside of the knee joint.  
❌ Fibular head subluxation:
Incorrect: In this condition, tenderness to palpation is found at the fibular head, not at the lateral femoral epicondyle as seen in this patient. Also a prominence may be visible at the area of the fibular head.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the clinic with worsening swelling and pain in his left knee. The pain has been ongoing for weeks and worsens with knee flexion. The patient works as a plumber and spends most of the day on his knees working in crawl spaces. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes and takes amlodipine and metformin daily. The patient smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks three beers on the weekends. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 146/75 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. The patient can fully flex and extend the knee and bear weight without significant pain. Physical examination is notable for the findings seen below, and a radiograph of the left knee is also shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with anterior knee pain and evidence of significant prepatellar bursal swelling from fluid accumulation. These findings are consistent with prepatellar bursitis.

Knee bursitis is a common condition that arises secondary to inflammation of bursa sacs surrounding the knee joint. Within the knee there are multiple bursal or fluid-filled synovial sacs that help to lubricate and cushion the skin, tendons, and bones. The commonly inflamed or injured bursa includes the prepatellar, infrapatellar, suprapatellar, and pes anserine bursa. Prepatellar and infrapatellar bursitis commonly occur in patients with chronic trauma to the anterior knee, such as those involved in professions who spend most of their day on their knees (e.g. plumbers). Suprapatellar bursitis is less common and often arises due to regression failure of the transverse septum formed in embryonic life between the suprapatellar plica and knee joint. The pes anserine bursa is located medially and commonly presents as swelling and pain at the medial aspect of the knee.

Clinically, knee bursitis presents as pain and swelling of the affected bursa without significant restrictions in the passive or active range of motion. The bursae are located extra-articularly, meaning the joint space itself remains unaffected when bursitis ensues. As a result, mobility within the joint itself remains unchanged. Additional clinical features include a preference to hold the knee in extension, warmth, erythema, and tenderness to palpation. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, but definitive diagnosis may involve MRI.  

Option Analysis

✅ Prepatellar bursitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Patellar fracture:
Incorrect: This radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of bony abnormalities and this patient’s symptoms have been going on for weeks.  
❌ Septic arthritis:
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is in the differential of unilateral knee swelling. However, it is unlikely in this case given that the patient is afebrile, is able to bear weight on the affected knee, and can fully flex and extend the knee.  
❌ Pes anserine bursitis:
Incorrect: Pes anserine bursitis typically presents with pain and swelling on the medial aspect of the knee, not anteriorly as seen in this patient.
❌ Patellar tendonitis:
Incorrect: Patellar tendonitis will often present with anterior knee pain. However, significant swelling is typically not seen.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of pain and stiffness in her shoulders, knees, and lower back, which has worsened over the past year. She also endorses reduced sleep, frequent nighttime awakenings, and reduced appetite. Her partner notes that she has been irritable and no longer enjoys going out for walks or playing with their children. The patient’s father died by suicide at 30, and her paternal uncle has a social anxiety disorder. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and her blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals tenderness at her shoulder, wrist, and knee joints. There is tenderness to palpation over the thoracolumbar spine. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities, and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ throughout. Laboratory testing is ordered and shown below. The patient is started on a medication for her condition. Which of the following receptors will most likely be targeted by this new medication?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  36% 
 Leukocyte count  6,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  350,000/mm3 
 TSH   4.0 
 ESR   12 mm/h 
 Creatinine kinase  88 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic, widespread musculoskeletal pain and cognitive and mood disturbances in the setting of normal laboratory results. She most likely has fibromyalgia and can be started on a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI).  

Fibromyalgia is a chronic pain syndrome most commonly affecting women between 20-50 years old. It presents with chronic, widespread musculoskeletal pain, stiffness, and paraesthesias. Physical examination is likely to reveal tender points on bony prominences. Laboratory investigations, including creatinine kinase and TSH, are typically within normal limits. Treatment of fibromyalgia includes patient education, sleep hygiene, regular aerobic exercise, and initiation of SNRI or tricyclic antidepressant therapy.  

Duloxetine is an SNRI used in the management of fibromyalgia. It inhibits serotonin and norepinephrine transporters on the presynaptic neuronal membrane, thereby increasing the levels of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft. Dulotxetine also has analgesic properties, which makes it beneficial in treating chronic pain syndromes.    
Other indications for duloxetine include diabetic neuropathic pain, stress urinary incontinence in women, and major depressive disorder.    

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

 

Option Analysis

❌ GABA mediated chloride channels :
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines act on GABA mediated chloride channels and increase the frequency with which they open. However, benzodiazepines are not indicated in the treatment of fibromyalgia.   
❌ Thyroid receptor proteins :
Incorrect: Hypothyroid myopathy can present with nonspecific myalgia and stiffness. Proximal muscle weakness with involvement of the shoulder and hip girdles is common. Laboratory testing would reveal a raised creatine kinase and elevated TSH. Thyroid replacement therapy (levothyroxine), which binds to thyroid receptor proteins, is the treatment of choice. However, hypothyroid myopathy is unlikely in this patient given her normal TSH and CK levels.   
✅ Norepinephrine and serotonin transporter:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Dopamine and 5-HT2 serotonin receptors :
Incorrect: Antipsychotics, such as clozapine and olanzapine, are dopamine and serotonin antagonists. They can be used to treat conditions ranging from schizophrenia to bipolar disorder. However, these agents are not used in the treatment of fibromyalgia.  
❌ Dopamine and norepinephrine receptors :
Incorrect: Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that inhibits dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake. It helps treat the major depressive disorder (MDD) in patients attempting to quit smoking. It is not the agent of choice in treating chronic pain syndromes like fibromyalgia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of difficulty wearing her shoes due to medial eminence of the right big toe. She is a dancer which requires her to work for twelve hours a day wearing specially fitted, tight closed shoes. The patient also reports pain worse with weight-bearing and when wearing her shoes. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows lateral deviation of the right great toe and enlargement of a medially deviated first metatarsal head. Skin over the enlarged toe is hard, warm, and red. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s toe pain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lateral deviation of the great toe and enlargement of the medially deviated first metatarsal head, suggestive of hallux valgus (bunion).

Hallux valgus is a progressive foot deformity that occurs when the first metatarsal head deviates medially, producing a painful bump causing the hallux to compensate with lateral deviation. Patients usually present with a prominent bump at the medial side of the metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP) joint.

Common risk factors include gender (women), footwear (tight pointed shoes), congenital deformity, or chronic achilles tension. Symptoms can range in severity from mild to severe discomfort, aggravated by standing, walking, or wearing narrow or stiff shoes. Examination and radiographs reveal the diagnosis.    Pressure and friction from prolonged hallux valgus deformity can lead to the development of corn(s), which are hyperkeratotic localized overgrowths.    

Option Analysis

❌ Gout :
Incorrect: Patients with gout often report a relatively sudden onset of severe symptoms including pain, swelling, and redness. This patient’s deformity developed insidiously. 
❌ Hallux rigidus :
Incorrect: Patients with hallux rigidus will typically present with pain, stiffness, and swelling in the first MTP joint, aggravated by repetitive dorsiflexion at the MTP joint. Physical examination will reveal limited and often painful range of motion of the big toe, along with crepitus. Prominent osteophytes on the dorsal aspect of the joint are usually visible and palpable. Lateral deviation of the great toe with enlargement of the medially deviated first metatarsal head is seen in hallux valgus. 
✅ Hallux valgus :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Charcot arthropathy :
Incorrect: Charcot joint presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma and impaired proprioception and sensation of pain. Patients often have underlying diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Turf toe :
Incorrect: Turf toe refers to an acute injury at the MTP joint when the great toe is forced superiorly injuring the plantar plate. A classic mechanism is an athlete jamming his or her foot against a hard surface. Prominent enlargement on the medial foot is suggestive of hallux valgus deformity.
